Description: Hello, sir. I think we can settle to this mountain. It seems reliable.
We saw many settlements fall during our travels. We must survive.
Chief, a mild earthquake occurred from the volcano.
If we boil our rations into a thin soup, we can feed every hungry soul today.
Mixing ground ash into the soup makes it feel thicker, but it hurts the belly.
Watering down the gruel feeds everyone, but the bellies will rumble.
The ash preserves the fallen husks. Should we turn our deads into a desperate feast?
A hearty stew made with our best meat will lift everyone’s spirits in this cold.
Adding spicy volcanic salts to the morning soup will help the workers dig faster.
Obsidian shards are deep in the muscle. Surgery might save them or cost a limb.
Keeping the ash-sick people alive will quickly fill our limited medical posts.
The beds are full in medical posts. Should we put two patients per bed to treat more people?
I can use high-pressure steam to clean wounds, but it will be very painful.
A dedicated Sanctuary Terrace for the dying would free up our basalt medical posts.
Triage lets me save the workers first, but the weak will be left behind.
The Sanctuary is overcrowded. Should we cut their rations to feed the workers?
Our healing salts are low; we must only treat those who can still dig the ash today
The fallen need a sacred spot. An ash crypt on the silent slope would give us dignity.
We have no room for graves. We should dump the dead into the deep ash pits for now.
A ritual of ash will honor the fallen and strengthen the faith of those remaining.
The ash keeps the dead intact. Their organs could mend our dying workers today.
The fallen can enrich our terrace moss beds. It is grim, but it will feed the living.
A tremor is coming. We must run emergency shifts to brace the terraces today.
Working from dawn’s glow to the lava’s light will finish the terraces sooner.
The lower vents are clogging. I need a crew to work 24 hours to clear the sulfur.
The children have small hands. They could sift the ash for charcoal in the safe zones.
We are drowning in ash. Every hand, even the smallest, must shovel or the city falls.
The steam pipes are bursting. Only the children can fit in the hot vents to patch them.
A sealed nursery in the inner basalt would protect the children from the ash-lung.
The young can learn to grind healing salts. They would save many lives in the medical posts.
The youth are small and fast. They can monitor the steam valves in the narrow shafts.
An Obsidian Ring lets workers vent their rage through duels. It lifts the gloom.
Disputes are slowing the dig. A formal duel in the ring would settle blood with blood.
An Alehouse would let the workers drown their sorrows in ash-wine after a shift.
The workers are breaking. A house of physical comfort would keep them digging the ash.
A small ration of lichen brandy would warm the workers' hearts in the cold ash.
A Basalt Chapel will offer our people a sanctuary to pray and find true peace.
Small shrines at the terrace edges will give workers strength as they face the ash.
An evening vigil at the shrines will steady our hearts before the cold night.
Kitchens on the terraces could serve hot lichen soup to frozen workers.
A Hall of Healing would allow us to treat the ash-lung and pray for the dying.
A Cathedral over the Great Vent would kindle a light our people sorely need.
The Faith Keepers will patrol the terraces to keep our city faithful.
Let the faithful denounce the wicked. The mountain’s heat demands purity.
Those who stray will be bound to the outer pillars to reflect in the falling ash.
Sentries at the terrace rim will guard the streets and deter troublemakers.
A morning roll call at the main vent will clarify tasks and ensure order.
Order Halls will organize a militia to keep peace throughout the terraces.
The Watch will patrol our paths to ensure safety and discipline.
If the Foreman patrols the sites, efficiency will peak across the vents.
The Information Hub will guide public opinion and align everyone's efforts.
A Prison will isolate those who threaten our stability and keep others safe.
Steam-Horn Agitators will use speakers to push efficiency and duty.
An Obsidian Oath will bind every citizen to our single, clear purpose.
If the discipline breaks in Prison, force will be used to restore the city's discipline.
Steam Hubs would pipe volcanic heat to the terraces the core cannot reach.
Placing Steam Hubs along the slopes will keep those areas warm and safe.
Placing Steam Hubs along certain streets would keep those areas warm and help people endure the cold.
Internal heaters would warm buildings that don’t get enough heat from vents.
Heaters in the Hall of Healing would help the sick recover much faster.
Heaters in the cookhouses keep the lichen soup hot and help people survive.
A Hothouse grows ash-roots using vent heat, securing food when hunts fail.
The sulfur-tuber harvest is massive. The cycles are growing stronger.
The crops withered in the frost. If this continues, starvation will follow.
A thief is breaking into the Hothouse. Someone is stealing the ash-roots.
A gray blight has struck the tubers. It is a plague born of the ash.
The blight is spreading fast. We must contain it or lose the Hothouse.
The Hothouse is sealed. We will have no harvests until the blight dies.
The plague jumped to the workers. Half the colony is gone. Hope is lost.
Hunter Huts on the terrace would let us track animals across the frozen ash plains.
The storm took my party, Chief. I am the only one who made it back through the ash.
The party is back. We’ve brought plenty of raw food for the Cookhouses.
We’ve spotted a White Deer near the ridge. It’s rare and fast. Should we chase it?
We brought down the White Deer. Its meat is rich, and its hide is thick.
We can build Great Elevator in city for explorers. It will speed up things while carrying stuff to the terraces.
Venturing into the frost may yield supplies or survivors in the ash.
We found a shivering group. They beg for the volcano’s heat. Let them in?
The city is swelling with survivors. We need more guards to keep the peace.
A storm is heading our way. It will be effective for five days… and it looks brutal.
The storm is here. The vents are choking as the city braces for the impact.
Homes are freezing. Ash-lung and frostbite spread faster than we can heal.
The Deep-Vents are frozen solid. Diggers cannot survive the freezing gloom.
The cold in the deep floors took them. They are frozen into the ash-veins.
I sent the crews home. Forcing work in this frost would lead to a massacre.
We’ve run out of raw food. With the hunters unable to go out, there’s nothing left to cook.
The sky is clearing. The storm has passed. The city breathes once more.
The Great Vent has gone dark. The city is a frozen tomb. All is lost.
A Workshop lets us use vent-heat to research new tech and push ideas forward.
Iron prosthetics would let the injured return to the terraces and work again.
With new prostheses, our amputees regain their purpose and their place in the city.
We cannot feed the broken. They must be exiled to the wastes to save the rest.
A Bath House uses geothermal runoff to clean the ash and lift the city's spirit.
A fight broke out in the Bath House over water heat. We must act now.
Spacious Quarters give families room to breathe, rekindling hope in the terrace.
Denser Housing fits more people per terrace, though sickness spreads faster.
A Dispensary uses experimental salts for the dying. It might save the lost.
The sulfur-salts worked! A worker once thought dead has returned to the dig.
Patients have waking dreams of a Volcano-god. Should we halt the salt treatments?
Stricter safety means people work with less haste but far greater care.
Regular gear maintenance keeps our steam-tools in safe operating condition.
Shorter shifts prevent overwork, leading to fewer mistakes in the dark.
The crews are rested. If we push them now, we can maximize our output.
The ash is piling up too fast. If we don't double the shifts, the roofs will collapse.
If we give extra rations to those working extended shifts, they’ll have the strength to keep going.
Coordinating shifts reduces downtime and keeps the vents running smoothly.
A Terrace Syndicate is forming. They may soon challenge our authority.
The Syndicate demands a voice. They wish to represent the interests of labor.
I lead the Syndicate and speak for those who keep the vents open.
If the ash-lung spreads and food fails, the Syndicate will call a strike.
We need a hall on the mid-terrace where the Syndicate can speak freely.
The workers are angry. For a fair price, I can calm the storm for you.
We must keep the Syndicate in check before they undermine the city's order.
Everyone must shovel ash, engineers and workers alike. No exceptions.
Work must be done. Efficiency comes before the comfort of the Syndicate.
The Syndicate will form a militia to guard the workers from the shadows.
The Guild is forming to organize the engineers and master the machines.
I oversee the safety and discipline of every vent and turbine.
Regular inspections by the Guild will motivate the crews to work harder.
Promoting loyal workers to Elite status sets a proper example for the rest.
Security Outposts ensure the safety of our technical staff while they work.
Our best minds deserve better quarters. Excellence should be rewarded.
To keep efficiency high, we must build a Penal Colony in the sulfur mines for Convicts.
Guild guards should ensure every employee returns to the vents. No excuses.
Troublemakers can be convicted without trial to keep order and expand labor.
Convicts must stay out of the Hall of Healing. Save resources for the loyal.
Someone left a note at the Sanctuary Terrace, thanking us for building it. It seems it truly helped.
Sir, someone left a note at the nursery, thanking us for building them. It seems they brought real comfort.
One of the children was injured at work. Do we give them a day off to recover?
A mother refused to send her daughter to work. How should we respond?
Working children demand extra food. They say the heavy ash-work warrants it.
A woman clings to her dead husband in the Ash-Pit. Should we bury him now?
A man collapsed and died during the Emergency Shift. He was saying that he didn't sleep a day. Do we end the work now?
A man died in a duel. The people are questioning this brutal practice.
One of the men assigned to the emergency shift has refused to work. How should we respond?
The emergency workers are demanding extra food for all the overtime they’ve put in.
The people you pushed to work harder are moving slowly now. They don’t believe we’ll survive this hell. Should we end the shift?
The workers you ordered to stay for the emergency shift returned to work without a single complaint.
People are starting to question why we keep calling so many emergency shifts. Should we stop them for now?
The workers are exhausted from these extended shifts. Should we grant them a break?
A worker took their life in the Red Vents. The workers and people are shaken.
There’s a drunken man shouting in the Cookhouse… saying there’s no hope left. He’s stirring everyone up.
There’s a drunken man shouting in the Cookhouse… saying there’s no hope left. He’s stirring everyone up.
There’s a drunken man shouting in the Cookhouse again… saying there’s no hope left. He’s upsetting everyone.
One of our engineers wants to improve our surgery. He’s devised a method that could reduce the number of amputations.
A man who’s lost his hand says he can’t work… and can’t pay for a house. He’s asking us to build a Sanctuary Terrace.
One of our men didn’t arrive for work today. He says the Faith Keepers blocked his way… trying to force him to change his beliefs.
Sir, some of the amputees are asking to work in the Cookhouse. They can’t return to the mines, but they still want to contribute.
An amputee was caught stealing from the stockpiles. He took materials to try making a prosthesis for himself.
To save a patient’s life, I had to perform an amputation. They’ll survive… but they won’t be able to work anymore.
One of our people is close to death. If we don’t remove the leg, we may lose him entirely.
The man whose leg we removed is thanking us. He knows we saved his life.
The man whose leg we didn’t remove… he’s died from gangrene. We couldn’t stop it.
Many are joining our prayers now. The city feels lighter… happier, even.
The engineer who pursued surgery improvement has reported success. His method works.
We’ve discovered a hidden stash of food. We’d like to distribute it among the people.
People on the streets are arguing about the Faith Keepers and their methods. Tension is rising.
People thanking us to open new kitchens on some of the Terraces, sir.
A dying man left a note. He wrote that he can die in peace… and that the city is in good hands, thanks to you.
People have begun visiting the Chapel again. It seems they truly needed this place of peace.
A family still believes in the Volcano god. They keep relics from their former faith.
Some of our people say penance should be a choice, not a duty. They believe no one should be forced into it.
Some of our people say penance should be a choice, not a duty. They believe no one should be forced into it.
A man has brought us a long list of names that believes in the Volcano god.
Sir, Faith Keepers dragged an old man from his house, trying to force him to submit to their beliefs.
A man has come forward saying his neighbors are planning a protest. We should decide how to handle it.
A woman claims her neighbors are hoarding food and supplies. We should decide how to respond.
A man from the family you allowed to keep their relics is frightened. Someone has marked their door with Volcano painting.
The Faith Keepers are still going from home to home, collecting relics of the Volcano god. Some families are growing nervous.
The Faith Keepers are still going from home to home, collecting relics of the old religion. Some families are growing nervous.
A young girl told us her mother said to one of our Faith Keepers that he’s going to burn in hell. Word is spreading fast.
A woman came to see you. She’s denouncing one of the Faith Keepers, saying he’s doing whatever he pleases to people.
People have begun leaving their personal charms and beads at the shrines. It seems the shrines truly help keep their spirits up.
A man told me his faith had died long ago… but after visiting the Cathedral, he says he can finally see a future again.
The Alehouse is poisoning people’s minds. We should cut its opening hours before it leads them astray.
One of the Agitators has been vandalized. Someone stripped parts from it during the night.
A mother has come to speak with you. She says a group of children beat her boy.
Sir… the Sentries have been beating inmates in the Prison. One has died, and another is badly injured.
People are protesting in front of the Prison. They’re furious about the inmates who died.
A group of workers have started organizing their workplace on their own. They say it’ll make them more efficient.
A group of drunk men are causing a disturbance. The peace is slipping.
A child came to the Order Hall today and handed a small toy to one of our sentry. Saying he should carry it on his patrols.
A prisoner insulted one of our sentry. The guard struck him with his baton and knocked him out.
A child climbed up towards Volcano and slipped… but one of our sentry caught them just in time.
The Watch discovered a frozen body. His coworkers tied him up as punishment… and left him to the cold.
One of our citizens insulted the Watch. They didn’t let it go… and now that man is in the medical post.
Sir… one of our people that protesting was beaten by the sentries so severely that he’s close to death.
A man is giving a speech to a small crowd… accusing you of failing the city.
The Watch report that a woman attacked them during their patrol. They’re asking how to proceed.
An engineer was accused of trying to turn some workers against you… but he insists that isn’t true.
The sentry who knocked that man out is drunk. He’s chasing people through the streets and hitting them with his baton.
One of our citizens is refusing to sign the Obsidian Oath. How should we respond?
A man was assaulted by his neighbor. She claims he informed on her and took matters into her own hands.
One of our informants was attacked on his way home from the Cookhouse. Someone wanted to silence him.
A woman was assaulted by her neighbor. He claims she informed on him, and he lashed out.
Our Watch have detained a man they suspect of disloyalty. They’re awaiting your decision.
A man is openly protesting against the abuse within our penitentiary system. People are starting to gather around him.
One of the prisoners is complaining about the cold in the cells. He says they can barely endure it.
The prisoner who complained about the cold… we found him dead in his cell this morning.
The prisoner who complained about the cold was taken to the medic. His arm had to be removed to save his life.
One of our informers has been abusing her position… she’s blackmailing citizens for favors.
A poet was found dead. His writings spoke of loss… and the death of hope.
There’s been a terrible accident in one of our terraces. Almost an entire team of workers has been killed.
Sir, our medic reports an outbreak of venereal disease because of the physical pleasure. It’s spreading quickly.
Sir, people are still falling sick because of their pleasures. The problem isn’t going away.
People have started using the Bath House for… other things. It’s becoming a concern.
Sir, people are frightened. Criminals roam the streets, and there’s no space left to hold any more prisoners.
The people wish for ceremonial funerals at the Ash-Grave to honor the dead.
Our people wish to hold ceremonial funerals at the cemetery. They say it brings comfort and dignity to their grief.
Several workers at the construction site passed out and fell into the machinery. The experimental drugs from the Dispensary caused it.
One of the men died from overwork today. His record shows he was a rapist and a murderer.
LeftText: A death still is a death

Description: The Watch have been sending some workers to Prison without trial men they call troublemakers. Now the people are protesting.
One of the amputees refuses to go home. His company will stop paying him the moment he does.
The Priest demands we ban the sulfur-ale. He says it leads to sin and rage.
Sir, a worker woman suspected of attempted sabotage is complaining that a sentry subjected her to an invasive body search.
Engineers caught signs of deliberate damage on the Steam Hubs. Sabotage!
There’s a man who brings trouble to the workplace every morning. The others are tired of dealing with him.
The Watch want to speak with you. The workers keep stopping their tasks to protest.
A woman was caught stealing our supplies. She’s complaining about the body search, says the older folks are never suspects.
A friend of those troublemakers has been visiting them in the Prison, reading their rights aloud.
The workers want your permission to form their own Syndicate. They’re waiting for your decision.
Giving so much power to the Syndicate might be the end of this city. Their decisions could put everything at risk.
The Syndicate is asking for a day off to celebrate a special occasion, but the Guild disagrees, they want to continue working.
We’re demanding a Bath House. The workers need it and we expect you to approve it.
That troublemaking worker… he’s suddenly disappeared this morning. No one’s seen him.
We’re asking for morning tea from the Cookhouse every day. The workers deserve at least that to start their shift.
We want religion banned in the workplaces. We don’t care what anyone believes the job must come first.
A friend of those troublemakers is proposing that prisoners should work and paid half the usual instead of sitting in a cell.
A group of workers attacked our Watch with batons they stole from the Order Hall.
We’ve had a good meeting. The workers agreed everyone will put in extra work today.
One of the workers has an idea that could save resources while building the new structure.
A fire broke out at the construction site. Several workers are injured and the damage is severe.
Sir, one of the engineers is shouting near the digging site. Saying that he has a degree, yet he’s still being sent to the digging work.
The workers want to celebrate a ‘Day of the Volcano’ They say it deserves its own moment.
A worker lost his temper and slapped a sentry. The sentry is demanding punishment.
A shipment found by the explorers, a fine tobacco. Should we share it with the workers?
We need overseers to supervise the engineers. With proper oversight, the work can be done without mistakes.
I’m demanding we change the Agitator slogans to align with the engineers. It will keep the message consistent across the city.
The Agitator is insulting the workers now. Ever since the Inspector changed its slogans.
Our people have been hungry for days. They’re eating so little… it’s starting to show.
Sir, our people have been starving for days. They’re demanding food right now.
The workers caught the man they believe started the fire. They say he was seen near the site just before it happened.
A worker assigned as a medic mixed the medicines wrong and poisoned the patients. He claims he was following the manuals the engineers provided.
Sir, people are growing concerned about the untreated sick. We may need more Medical Posts.
We need more Medical Posts if we want to treat all of our people properly.
Sir… our people are dying in the streets. We need new Medical Posts, or we won’t keep up.
Some of our people are worried about their cold homes. They could fall sick any day now.
Sir, some of our people are falling ill because their homes are freezing.
People are growing angry about the cold houses. If we do nothing, they’ll start dying.
Some of our people are worried about how cold their workplaces are. They could fall sick at this rate.
Some of our people are refusing to come to work because of the cold. They say it’s unbearable.
People are growing angry about the cold workplaces. If we do nothing, some of them may start dying.
Some of our people are sleeping outside. They’ve nowhere warm to go.
Sir, the people sleeping outside are falling sick. They can’t work like this… we need to do something.
The people sleeping outside will die if we do nothing. The cold is already taking its toll.
Chief, nights are getting restless. We should do more patrolling. It may scare people but will keep us safe.
Chief, Patrol found a man collapsed in a side alley. He would’ve died out there. My men are waiting for instructions.
The man we found in a side alley has thanked us for saving his life.
The man we found in a side alley has thanked us for saving his life.
We saw a dead body while patrolling the side alley. That was the man we found recently.
Chief, A fight broke out at the supply terrace during distribution. Sentries can disperse the crowd.
A man found dead after the fight at supply terrace.
Chief, A group gathered after hours near main terrace. No violence yet. My men await orders.
Chief, with injuries rising, I don’t have enough men to cover all routes tonight. I need you to choose what we leave unguarded.
Chief, A patrol caught someone stealing heating parts. He ran. We can chase or secure the remaining stock.
The terraces are encased in ice. Our struggle ends in the cold, white ash.
Hope fades completely. The people stop believing in tomorrow, and your rule collapses quietly in the cold.
Your promises grow too grand. Reality breaks beneath impossible expectations, and the city turns on you.
No one resists anymore. The city grows eerily quiet as its people lose the will to react — or to live.
Anger boils over. The streets erupt, and your reign ends amid fire, shouts, and broken authority.
Rules no longer matter. Without order, the city fractures, and leadership becomes meaningless.
Your grip tightens too much. Fear replaces loyalty, and you are removed before the city breaks entirely.
Belief crumbles. Without faith in anything greater, the people abandon you — and each other.
Faith turns fanatical. Devotion becomes violence, and you are consumed by the fire you allowed to spread.
Our people worrying about living on the mountain.
As you said, Chief. No one could have imagined that one day we are going to live in volcano.
People started to work to settle themselves by digging terraces on slope.
Chief, these fire-bricks keeping us warm, we can bring them where we live.
Chief, we can have obsidians as many as we want in this mountain. We can reinforce our terraces by shaping spikes and placing them.
No damage yet, sir. But we should prepare our settlement for further.
These earthquakes seems to be happen in often, sir. We will never know.
Sir, we’ve walked for weeks. I'm glad we found this volcano. I want to help to our people for their settlement.
We've dug our terrace and settled with our tents. Now we are ready to help our people.
Our people managed to gather enough wood to build shelters, sir.
Chief, after all we endured, I believe we can survive!
Sir, we need a foreman if we want to do our work efficiently. I can talk with people and make a list for you.
Here are the people who can be our foreman. You can talk to them and hire whoever you see fit.
Hello, sir. I’ve kept crews moving longer than most plans survive the cold.
LeftText: How do you decide the pace of work?
RightText: How do you respond when output drops?

Description: I go by instinct, it usually works out.
I tighten schedules and see who keeps up.
Accidents just happen in the cold.
I expect men to be careful.
Should we hire him, sir? Or you want to move next one?
I’ve overseen shifts for years and learned what I still don’t know.
LeftText: How do you handle exhausted workers?
RightText: How do you keep morale steady?

Description: I try a few things and hope one helps.
LeftText: What do you do after an accident?

Description: I do not, morale comes and goes.
LeftText: What do you do after an accident?

Description: I follow procedure and wait for instructions.
I wish I knew, sir.
Should we hire him, sir? Or you want to move next one?
Foreman by experience, survivor by habit.
LeftText: How do you deal with slow workers?
RightText: How do you deal with complaints?

Description: Slow crews usually fix themselves.
Complaints sound louder than problems.
Repetition means it belongs in a report.
Serious things are above my pay.
Should we hire him, sir? Or you want to move next one?
I’ve been underground long enough to stop pretending it makes sense.
LeftText: What keeps men working in this cold?

Description: Habit lasts longer than hope.
LeftText: How do you deal with despair?

Description: They stop believing effort matters.
LeftText: How do you deal with despair?

Description: I keep them busy enough not to notice.
I do not raise spirits, I lower expectations.
This guy was the last candidate sir, we should hire him without a choice.
My bread is gone! If there's no law here, people will start fighting soon.
I saw the light hit the volcano just right. It’s a sign we’ll survive.
Someone was prowling near our tent last night. We feel so unprotected, Chief.
The air tastes like burnt stone, Chieftain. My throat is raw from the ash. Do we have any spare cloths for masks?
My daughter is missing! Please, tell Captain to send a search party out there.
We are building shelters with the wood we've gathered, sir.
The wind screams through gaps. We need more insulation, or we'll freeze.
My hammer is gone! Without guards watching the site, work will stop, Chief.
I’ve stitched a small cross for our door. It brings us peace. May I?
My boots are split. I can't feel my toes. Is there no protection for us?
She was found on a cliff looking down to the landscape. It's a miracle from above!
Steam is leaking! If Captain doesn't secure the perimeter, more will break.
Those who believe the volcano, they want to sacrifice their food.
Sir, people want to gather wood to improve our tents to shelter at least. But they might get sick.
Someone stole the blankets from our shelter! Captain must find them, Chief.
The frost on the shelter window looks like an angel. It's a sign of mercy!
A stranger was eyeing our shelter. We need a watchman on this street.
We've opened our shelter to the orphans. It’s what the Great Spirit wants.
The community wood pile is half-empty. Someone is stealing from our shelters!
I saw someone hiding planks under her bed. She’s old, but a thief is a thief.
I only wanted to fix my  shelter's floor. Please, don't cast me out.
We can't feel our hands, Chief. We need to stop the clearing for an hour.
Title: John

Description: Some of our people are sitting idle. Others are starting to drop their tools too.
Title: Percival

Description: We'll work, but we want an extra ration tonight for the frostbite. Deal?
Title: John

Description: Chief, the vents from the volcano... it sounds like voices. Can you hear it?
I’ve marked our shelter with a soot-cross. The voices say it will keep us warm.
A volcano believer gathering people to worship near the dangerous area.
The volcano roared and the ice melted! The Great Spirit has heard us, Chief!
I saw someone is hoarding extra fire-brick. I saw the ash on their rug.
We've lost one of our worker and his body has frozen. The soil is too hard to dig.
A supply wagon broke an axle in the wastes. To save the food, we must leave the heavy tools behind.
We only have enough to keep the children from shaking! Don't take our heat.
The fire-brick is back in the pile. Now others know the rules apply to everyone.
Sir, we have to start hunting really soon. Otherwise no food will remain in few days.
Here are the people who wants to be hunters and bring food to home.
I've never used any kind of gun before sir. I can learn to be good for this city.
I was joined to scouting club at high school so I know the basics out there.
I was at the army before all going down sir. I know how to use guns.
I was hunting with my dad before all of this storm came. I know tracking good.
You have to hire more hunters sir, let's talk to these people again I'd say.
Good job sir, we can start hunting now!
Sir, I'm here to suggest we can ask our people if there are engineers among them.
Here are the people who did engineering in their past life.
I've been turning wrenches since I was a child.
LeftText: How do you handle Steam Hub maintenance?
RightText: What do you do when the pipes leak?

Description: I kick it. If that fails, I find a bigger boot and a louder curse.
LeftText: How important is new research to you?
RightText: Tell me, do you ever actually sleep?

Description: Stuff a rag in it and scream at it until it stops. It works for my knees
LeftText: How important is new research to you?
RightText: Tell me, do you ever actually sleep?

Description: Books are just heavy things that don't burn as well as coal.
Only during the Captain’s speeches. The boredom is a natural sedative.
Should we hire this engineer sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
I treat my tools better than people. They’re more logical.
LeftText: How do you handle Steam Hub maintenance?
RightText: What do you do when the pipes leak?

Description: I whisper sweet orings to it. It’s the only way to keep the pistons happy.
LeftText: How important is new research to you?
RightText: Tell me, do you ever actually sleep?

Description: I seal them properly. I’m a mechanic, not a plumber in a bathtub.
LeftText: How important is new research to you?
RightText: Tell me, do you ever actually sleep?

Description: Very. If we don’t innovate, we’re just very organized, shivering icicles.
I blink occasionally. It’s like a tiny, disappointing vacation for my eyes.
Should we hire this engineer sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
I’ve survived three meltdowns! Well, I survived. The labs didn't.
LeftText: How do you handle Steam Hub maintenance?
RightText: What do you do when the pipes leak?

Description: I wait for the sparks! They’re like tiny, festive lights before the screaming starts.
LeftText: How important is new research to you?
RightText: Tell me, do you ever actually sleep?

Description: Free steam bath! Who needs layers of skin when you have humidity?
LeftText: How important is new research to you?
RightText: Tell me, do you ever actually sleep?

Description: If the research involves the words 'High Pressure' and 'Explosion,' I’m in.
Hard to sleep when you can taste the electricity in your fillings, Chief!
Should we hire this engineer sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
Physics is the only law that hasn't been frozen solid yet.
LeftText: How do you handle Steam Hub maintenance?
RightText: What do you do when the pipes leak?

Description: I negotiate with the machine. Currently, the boiler is winning the argument.
LeftText: How important is new research to you?
RightText: Tell me, do you ever actually sleep?

Description: I ask the steam politely to respect the laws of fluid dynamics.
LeftText: How important is new research to you?
RightText: Tell me, do you ever actually sleep?

Description: Without it, we’re just monkeys in very expensive, soot-covered coats.
I tried once, but the math in my dreams was wrong and it woke me up.
There are no candidates left sir. We must hire this one without any choice.
Sir, I want to find people who can cook and make a list for you. So we can we can eat proper meal.
Here are the people who did cooking in their past life.
I’ve cooked things that would make a vulture gag. Want a taste?
LeftText: Rations are low. How do you handle a food shortage?
RightText: We’re adding sawdust to the gruel. Any tips?

Description: Add more water. If they can still chew it, the soup is too thick.
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?

Description: Call it 'Fiber-Enriched Forest Delicacy.' They’ll still hate it, but they’ll be regular.
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?"

Description: Tell them to eat faster. Motivation is the best seasoning.
Pure, unadulterated spite. It's the only thing that stays hot.
Should we hire this cook sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
I studied in Paris before the frost. Now, I specialize in 'Snow-Cured Mystery'.
LeftText: Rations are low. How do you handle a food shortage?
RightText: We’re adding sawdust to the gruel. Any tips?

Description: It’s not a shortage, Chief. It’s a 'limited-time tasting event'!
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?

Description: Fine-milled pine provides a lovely, woody finish to the palate.
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?"

Description: Serve it in heated mugs? Or tell them it’s a savory popsicle.
Imagination! Because there sure isn't any actual meat in there.
Should we hire this cook sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
Meat is meat. Don't ask where I found it, and I won't lie to you.
LeftText: Rations are low. How do you handle a food shortage?
RightText: We’re adding sawdust to the gruel. Any tips?

Description: I’ll check the 'unused' graves. Meat shouldn't go to waste just because it's cold.
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?

Description: It helps the meat stick together. Like glue, but slightly more edible.
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?'

Description: Serve it raw. Can't freeze if it's already a brick of ice, right?
Knowing when to look away when the delivery arrives.
Should we hire this cook sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
A human is just a biological engine. I provide the fuel.
LeftText: Rations are low. How do you handle a food shortage?
RightText: We’re adding sawdust to the gruel. Any tips?

Description: Reduce the intake to 800 calories. They won't die, they'll just be very, very quiet.
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?

Description: Chemically, cellulose is just complex carbs. It's basically bread, if you squint.
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?"

Description: Add a drop of industrial grease. Lowers the freezing point and adds a lovely shine.
Efficiency. I’ve removed all the flavor to save on chewing energy.
There is no candidates left, sir. We should hire this guy.
Sir, since our engineer made exploring possible, I want to see if any people want to be explorer.
Here are the people who wants to be Explorer, sir.
I’ve walked to the horizon and back. My toes didn't make the return trip.
LeftText: A blizzard is closing in. Do you push through or dig in?
RightText: The compass is frozen solid. How do you find your way back?

Description: Dig in. The frost doesn't care how brave you are, but it hates a deep hole.
LeftText: We’re out of rations. What’s for dinner out there?
RightText: What's the weirdest thing you've found in the frost?

Description: I follow the smell of the Generator. It smells like home and lung cancer.
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?"

Description: Leather boots. Boil them long enough and they’re basically chewy steak.
A frozen gentleman holding an umbrella. Optimistic fellow.
Should we hire this explorer sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
If I stop moving, I'll freeze. If I keep moving, I can find anything useful for the city!
LeftText: A blizzard is closing in. Do you push through or dig in?
RightText: The compass is frozen solid. How do you find your way back?

Description: Push through! If you run fast enough, the snowflakes can't catch you!
LeftText: We’re out of rations. What’s for dinner out there?
RightText: What's the weirdest thing you've found in the frost?

Description: I leave a trail of very disappointed snowmen. Can't miss 'em.
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?"

Description: Snow. It’s like a meal, but with 100% fewer calories and more sadness.
A polar bear wearing a hat. Or maybe I was just hallucinating.
Should we hire this explorer sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
A map is just a list of places where people have already died. I’m making a new list.
LeftText: A blizzard is closing in. Do you push through or dig in?
RightText: The compass is frozen solid. How do you find your way back?

Description: Statistically, digging in increases survival by 40%. The other 60% is luck.
LeftText: We’re out of rations. What’s for dinner out there?
RightText: What's the weirdest thing you've found in the frost?

Description: I calculate the sun's position. Or I just follow the trail of dead scouts.
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?"

Description: Lichen. It tastes like dirt, but it’s high in... well, dirt.
A library where all the books were used for a giant campfire.
Should we hire this explorer sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
I don't know where I am, but look! I found a crate of canned peaches!
LeftText: A blizzard is closing in. Do you push through or dig in?
RightText: The compass is frozen solid. How do you find your way back?

Description: I usually trip and fall into a cave right before the wind picks up.
LeftText: We’re out of rations. What’s for dinner out there?
RightText: What's the weirdest thing you've found in the frost?

Description: I walk in circles until I hit something metallic. Usually the Generator.
LeftText: The soup is freezing in the bowls. What's your fix?
RightText: What is the secret ingredient in your 'Special'?"

Description: I found some 'mystery jerky' in an old sled. Don't ask, just chew.
A crate of pre-frost whiskey. I 'secured' it for the city's health.
There are no candidates left sir. We should hire this explorer.
Chief, cooking the meals at home doesn't work for all of our people. I'm suggesting that we need a Cookhouse.
Chief, we need medical post urgently. Otherwise I can't treat them properly at their house.
Sir, our people started to getting sick from cold and raw food. We should ask if there's anyone among us who understands medic.
Here are the people who studied medic in the past life.
If it's black, it's gone. Don't get attached to your limbs.
LeftText: How would you treat a person that has frostbite?
RightText: We’re out of medicine. What’s the substitute?

Description: Amputate. Better to lose a foot than a whole citizen.
LeftText: The infirmary is full. How do we clear beds?
RightText: What’s the weirdest thing you’ve used as a bandage?

Description: Sawdust and prayer. Mostly the sawdust.
LeftText: The infirmary is full. How do we clear beds?
RightText: What’s the weirdest thing you’ve used as a bandage?

Description: Discharge the ones who can still walk. Or crawl.
A frozen copy of the city laws. Kept the wound stiff!
Should we hire this one sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
A warm smile is the best medicine. And actual medicine. We have that, right?
LeftText: How would you treat a person that has frostbite?
RightText: We’re out of medicine. What’s the substitute?

Description: Warm water and a hug! Or, well... mostly just the warm water.
LeftText: The infirmary is full. How do we clear beds?
RightText: What’s the weirdest thing you’ve used as a bandage?

Description: Hot tea. It doesn't cure scurvy, but it feels like a lie we can believe in.
LeftText: The infirmary is full. How do we clear beds?
RightText: What’s the weirdest thing you’ve used as a bandage?

Description: Double-bunking! It’s not 'overcrowded,' it’s 'extra snug'.
A very long, very clean woolen scarf. He looked quite festive!
Should we hire this one sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
I’ve got a tonic for everything. Side effects include glowing in the dark.
LeftText: How would you treat a person that has frostbite?
RightText: We’re out of medicine. What’s the substitute?

Description: Rub some engine grease on it. Seals the heat right in!
LeftText: The infirmary is full. How do we clear beds?
RightText: What’s the weirdest thing you’ve used as a bandage?

Description: Fermented coal-juice. Makes you forget you’re even sick.
LeftText: The infirmary is full. How do we clear beds?
RightText: What’s the weirdest thing you’ve used as a bandage?

Description: Give them my 'Sleeping Draught.' They won't move for days.
Sausage casing. It was airtight, I’ll give it that.
Should we hire this one sir? Or you want to continue with next candidate?
The human body is just another machine. A very leaky, complaining machine.
LeftText: How would you treat a person that has frostbite?
RightText: We’re out of medicine. What’s the substitute?

Description: Leeches. I’ve bred a special 'Polar Leech' that enjoys the cold.
LeftText: The infirmary is full. How do we clear beds?
RightText: What’s the weirdest thing you’ve used as a bandage?

Description: Placebo. If they think they’re cured, the math usually follows.
LeftText: The infirmary is full. How do we clear beds?
RightText: What’s the weirdest thing you’ve used as a bandage?

Description: Automate the beds. If the patient doesn't improve, the bed ejects them.
Sticky soot and a prayer. It’s basically natural charcoal gauze.
No candidates left for interviewing sir. We should hire this one at all cost.
Sir, I want to gather people who wants to join us and pray together.
Sir, I can take care of our inventory.
Because no one else asked, sir. You should know what is happening with the inventory all the time.
Sir, our city is growing thanks to you!
Chief, one of the water pipe's pressure is going crazy, we should manually adjust them very quickly!
Great job, Chief! The water pipe restored now.
We failed to fix the water pipe leak sir.
Chief, our engineer fixed the radio that our explorer was brought. We have to adjust the frequency.
Great job, Chief! Now we will be able to hear who those call from radio for help.
We failed to find the correct frequency for the radio, sir.
Chief, a stranger arrived to the city and wanted to talk with you.
Hello, let me introduce myself first. I'm not telling my name to anyone so you can call me The Stranger.
Don't be so curious, Chief. It is not that good.
I'm traveling the survived cities across this country for trading and here I am now.
I'm trading what people need...
Do you want to take a look to my wares, Chief?
Do you want to take a look to my wares, Chief?
Chief, steam hub's heat drops very quickly! We must do something!
Great job, Chief! Now the steam hub is stable and running great!
We failed to stable it sir. Steam hub shut itself down and we must repair it now.
Chief, one of the water pipes started leaking! We must patch it!
Great job, Chief! Now the water pipe is stable and running great!
We failed to patch the water pipe, sir. Steam Hub shut itself down and we must repair the pipe now.

Chief, our medical post is buried under snow! We should clear it immediately! ;; Chief, one of the houses is buried under snow! We should clear it immediately! ;; Chief, our cookhouse is buried under snow! We should clear it immediately!
Great job, Chief! We cleared all the snow!
We were too late with clearing sir. We have to use extra supplies for our lost.
Chieftain, these fire-bricks are too heavy for the climb. Can we use smaller stones instead?
My brick is scorching the floor. Should I dig a deeper pit in the soil for safety?
We found a unique rock that stays hot for days. Send a team to that dangerous ledge for more?
Some families are hoarding extra fire-bricks in their tents while others freeze. Should we start rationing the stones?
I can carry twice as many bricks if I leave my heavy coat behind. Should I make the extra trips to warm the camp?
The ground under the food storage is getting too hot. Our dried meat is starting to char. Should we move the supplies further into the cold?
The ash is piling up on the tent roofs. If we don't clear it, they will collapse under the weight. Should I send the night shift to sweep?
The ash clouds above the peak are throwing blue sparks! Should we build a copper rod to lead the lightning away?
We found a small vent on the third terrace! It's blowing hot steam. Should we move the nursery tents there, or is the smell too strong?
The western terrace is beginning to crumble under the weight of the tents. We should drive obsidian spikes into the soil to stabilize it.
The paths connecting the terraces are freezing over. We could carve permanent stairs into the rock, but it will cost us many obsidian tools.
The ground under my tent is vibrating and getting much hotter. Should we evacuate this terrace?
Some of our people started to believe this volcano is a god.
There is no more room on the safe terraces! My family is forced to sleep on the edge of the drop. Can we dig higher up?
The family we have sent to higher levels got sick from the volcano gas, sir.
LeftText: Let them rest in lower levels

Description: Sir! The ground... it's moving! It's not the wind. The mountain is waking up!
There is a woman calls herself the Oracle. Crowds are gathering to hear her.
The Volcano is not a monster. It is a God. It protects us from the cold.
Never listen to that witch! She lost her mind and talks without thinking.
Volcano talks with us! It starves! We must give some of our foods. We should sacrifice!
We need more pressure vents! We must vent the Volcano's pressure at all cost!
Sir, our workers have been worried of the earthquakes we are going through.
Some of our people wants to give their food to the Volcano. They believe there is only one way to stop this.
Another Tremor!!!
Sir, we are trying to lower the pressures of mountain. We can still survive from this.
Yes. Let go of your struggle! Volcano is the only savior of this people.
Sir, our workers started to believe in Volcano. They want to follow the Oracle.
This witch lost her mind! Do not follow her! We must get rid of her.
Yes. Come, my children. Volcano calls us. We must walk into our salvation!
The city is empty. We followed her into the flame. No living souls remained here.
You don't have to struggle, accept its ways and everyone will survive.
One of the terraces is sliding! We'll hammer iron spikes into the rift to anchor it.
We must arrest this Witch! Make her stop talking and poisoning our people.
Sir, pressures are going down, mountain started to calm.
RightText: That's what I want to hear

Description: We must burn this witch with her god's fire. Let's throw her into the Volcano!
The city successfully controlled the Volcano and got rid of the Witch. This is the true salvation. Now everyone can live together in peace.
That's it! Can you not see? Volcano is pleased by the giving food.
Sir, we are trying to lower the pressures of mountain. We can still survive from this.
You don't have to struggle, accept its ways and everyone will survive.
We must arrest this Witch! Make her stop talking and poisoning our people.
Sir, pressures are not going down no matter we do! We must escape from here.
We must burn this witch with her god's fire. Let's throw her into the Volcano!
Chief... That witch is laughing while burning. She is not dying.
You should've listened to me...
While the city tries to burn the witch, volcano explodes and erase this city from the livings. The only one remains: The Witch and her god.
